tit.e: Prince Yamashiro no Otsutsukimawaka (Yamashiro no Otsutsukimawaka no Miko)
Prince Yamashiro no Otsutsukimawaka (Yamashiro no Otsutsukimawaka no Miko)
Prince Yamashiro no Otsutsukimawaka (Yamashiro no Otsutsukimawaka no Miko)

sen.j: 山代之大筒木真若王（やましろのおおつつきまわかのみこ、生没年不詳）は、『古事記』に伝える古墳時代の皇族（王族）。
sen.e: Prince Yamashiro no Otsutsukimawaka [(山代之大筒木真若王) 'Yamashiro no Otsutsukimawaka no Miko'; his date of birth and death are unknown] first appeared in the "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) as an Imperial family (royal family) during the Kofun period (tumulus period) in Japan.

Prince Yamashiro no Otsutsukimawaka (Yamashiro no Otsutsukimawaka no Miko; his date of birth and death are unknown) first appeared in the "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) as an Imperial family (royal family) during the Kofun period (tumulus period) in Japan.
sen.cmt: []とシングルクォートの削除しました。
sen.e: Prince Yamashiro no Otsutsukimawaka (Yamashiro no Otsutsukimawaka no Miko; his date of birth and death are unknown) first appeared in the "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) as an Imperial family (royal family) during the Kofun period (tumulus period) in Japan.

sen.j: 『古事記』によれば、父は彦坐王（ひこいますのみこ）で、母は袁祁都比売命（おけつひめのみこと）。
sen.e: According to the "Kojiki," the father of Prince Yamashiro no Otsutsukimawaka was Prince Hikoimasu (彦坐王), and his (Yamashiro no Otsutsukimawaka no Miko) mother was 'Oketsuhime no Mikoto' (袁祁都比売命)
According to the "Kojiki," the father of Prince Yamashiro no Otsutsukimawaka was Prince Hikoimasu (Hikoimasu no miko), and his mother was Oketsuhime no Mikoto.
sen.cmt: ひこいますのみこの読みを入れ、シングルクォートを削除し、２回目の (Yamashiro no Otsutsukimawaka no Miko) を削除し、ピリオドを挿入しました。
sen.e: According to the "Kojiki," the father of Prince Yamashiro no Otsutsukimawaka was Prince Hikoimasu (Hikoimasu no miko), and his mother was Oketsuhime no Mikoto.

sen.j: 同母弟に比古意須王（ひこおすのみこ）、伊理泥王（いりねのみこ）がいる。
sen.e: Prince Hikoosu [(比古意須王) Hikoosu no Miko] and Prince Irine [(伊理泥王) Irine no Miko] were his (Prince Yamashiro no Otsutsukimawaka) brothers, all with the same mother and father (Prince Hikoimasu).
Prince Yamashiro no Otsutsukimawaka had younger maternal half-brothers of Prince Hikoosu (Hikoosu no Miko) and Prince Irine (Irine no Miko).
sen.cmt: 同母弟を既定の語句に変更し、[]を削除し構文を変更しました。
sen.e: Prince Yamashiro no Otsutsukimawaka had younger maternal half-brothers of Prince Hikoosu (Hikoosu no Miko) and Prince Irine (Irine no Miko).

sen.j: また、開化天皇の孫、神功皇后の曽祖父に当たる。
sen.e: Additionally, Prince Yamashiro no Otsutsukimawaka was a grand child of the Emperor Kaika; he was also a great-grand father of the Empress Jingu.
Additionally, Prince Yamashiro no Otsutsukimawaka was a grandchild of the Emperor Kaika; he was also a great-grand father of the Empress Jingu.
Additionally, Prince Yamashiro no Otsutsukimawaka was a grandchild of the Emperor Kaika; he was also a great-grand father of the Empress Jingu.

sen.j: 王は伊理泥王の女・丹波能阿治佐波毘売（たにはのあじさはびめ）を妃とし、迦邇米雷王（かにめいかずちのみこ）を儲けた。
sen.e: Prince Yamashiro no Otsutsukimawaka married 'Taniwa no Ajisawabime' (丹波能阿治佐波毘売) as his princess; and she gave birth to Prince Kanimeikazuchi [(迦邇米雷王) Kanimeikazuchi no Miko].
Prince Yamashiro no Otsutsukimawaka married Taniwa no Ajisawabime as his princess; and she gave birth to Prince Kanimeikazuchi (Kanimeikazuchi no Miko).
sen.cmt: []とシングルクォートの削除しました。
sen.e: Prince Yamashiro no Otsutsukimawaka married Taniwa no Ajisawabime as his princess; and she gave birth to Prince Kanimeikazuchi (Kanimeikazuchi no Miko).

sen.j: 王の名は地名に由来しており、『和名類聚抄』に「山城国綴喜郡綴喜、豆々木」（現在の京田辺市普賢寺付近）と見える。
sen.e: The origin of the name for Prince Yamashiro no Otsutsukimawaka seemed to been taken from a location; this fact was supported by the writings of the "Wamyo Ruijusho" [Kango (Chinese characters)-Japanese Dictionary in mid Heian period]: "Tsutsuki (豆々木), Tsuzuki, Tsuzuki-gun County, Yamashiro Province (山城国 綴喜郡 綴喜)" (the current location is the area of Fugen-ji shimo in Kyotanabe City.)

The origin of the name for Prince Yamashiro no Otsutsukimawaka seemed to been taken from a location; this fact was supported by the writings of the "Wamyo Ruijusho" (Kango [Chinese characters]-Japanese Dictionary in mid Heian period): 'Tsutsuki, Tsuzuki, Tsuzuki-gun County, Yamashiro Province' (the current location is the area of Fugen-ji shimo in Kyotanabe City.)
sen.cmt: ()と[]の変更、また、クォート内に（）は入らないという規定のため、一部変更しました。
sen.e: The origin of the name for Prince Yamashiro no Otsutsukimawaka seemed to been taken from a location; this fact was supported by the writings of the "Wamyo Ruijusho" (Kango [Chinese characters]-Japanese Dictionary in mid Heian period): 'Tsutsuki, Tsuzuki, Tsuzuki-gun County, Yamashiro Province' (the current location is the area of Fugen-ji shimo in Kyotanabe City.)

sen.j: なお、同市は市制施行前まで綴喜郡田辺町であった。
sen.e: Additionally, Tsuzuki, Tsuzuki-gun County, Kyotanabe City was at one time Tanabe-cho, Tsuzuki-gun; this was up to the point of implementation and enforcement of the municipal organization system.
Additionally, Tsuzuki, Tsuzuki-gun County, Kyotanabe City was Tanabe-cho, Tsuzuki-gun before the implementation and enforcement of the municipal organization system.
Additionally, Tsuzuki, Tsuzuki-gun County, Kyotanabe City was Tanabe-cho, Tsuzuki-gun before the implementation and enforcement of the municipal organization system.
